name: oat grain production | oat grain | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/13734/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of oat grain (wet mass). This dataset has been extrapolated from an original dataset covering the geography Québec (Canada).;This activity was adapted to include the global average land use change (LUC) emissions according 2nd edition of the Quantis-modified tool developed by Blonk Consultants 'WFLDB-adapted-Blonk 2014 direct-land-use-change-assessment-tool_2015-05-18a.xlsx', tab. 'Country & land use unknown'. The size of the emission depends on (i) the relative crop expansion in all countries of the crop during the last 20 years and (ii) the corresponding, country specific land transformations. The current results are based on the average FAOSTAT data (harvested area) of 2009-2011 and 1989-1991. The weighted average is used which takes into account relative difference in crop expansion into primary forest, secondary forest, grassland, perennial and annual land.

This activity starts with soil cultivation after the harvest of the previous crop.

This activity ends after harvest and drying of grains at the farm gate. The dataset includes the inputs of seeds, mineral and organic fertilisers, pesticides and all machine operations and corresponding machine infrastructure and sheds. Machine operations are: soil cultivation, transport of seeds, fertilisers and pesticides to the field (15 km), sowing, fertilisation, weed control, pest and pathogen control, combine-harvesting, transport from field to farm or local drying centre and drying of grains. Direct field emissions are also included. The use of car, van or pick-up for servicing people, e.g. from farm to field, is not included in the activities. Note that there is likely irrigation involved at the GLO scale, but no data were specifically collected for the dataset since it is extrapolated from the QC-CA geography where no irrigation is applied.
category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/01:Crop and animal production, hunting and related service activities/011:Growing of non-perennial crops/0111:Growing of cereals (except rice), leguminous crops and oil seeds

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: This dataset has been copied from an original dataset covering the geography Québec. The uncertainty has been adjusted accordingly.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: This dataset has been extrapolated from an original dataset covering the geography of Quebec (Canada). Modelling of the Quebec dataset is described as follow: Transports are modelled with standard distances. Machine usage is modelled with Québec diesel consumptions and field works (Beauregard, 2013) and Swiss machines. Mineral fertilizer types are extrapolated from overall mineral fertilizers sales in Québec (APNC 2011). Organic fertilizer types are extrapolated from animal manure supply data, per region in Québec, communicated by the Ministry of Agriculture (MAPAQ). Data about agricultural management practices are from BPR (2008. Suivi 2007 du Portrait agroenvironnemental des fermes du Québec). Emissions are calculated with standard methods according to ecoinvent documentation (Nemecek and Schnetzer, 2011. '01 crop production-direct field emissions natural resources' v1.2, August 2011, available at https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/File/Reports) and the World Food LCA Database guidelines (Nemecek et al. 2014, available at http://www.quantis-intl.com/microsites/wfldb/), except for : 1) pesticides emitted fractions (modelled using PestLCI 2.0, a global model, considering Québec average conditions for model input parameters, and considering that the degradation/uptake fraction calculated by PestLCI is actually emitted to soil - see the supporting documentation '01 crop production - Québec.pdf' for rationale), 2) phosphorus and phosphate emissions (modelled using ODEP, a Québec model, considering geospatialized weighted average conditions for soil, hydrology, and agricultural management practices), and 3) ammonia emissions from organic fertilizers which are calculated according to Québec conditions and agricultural management practices (coefficients are taken from Parent et Gagné (2010 and 2013 update). Furthermore, an IPCC Tier 2 approach is used for N2O emissions using regional and ecodistrict-based emission factors (Rochette et al., 2008). Due to lack of comprehensive data on pesticides use for Québec, data from a 2008 survey in the neighbouring province of Ontario are used (OMAFRA, 2008). Uncertainty in terms of the variance of the logtransformed data is the default value as provided by the Data Quality Guidelines for ecoinvent v3 (available at http://www.ecoinvent.org/support/documents-and-files/). Details on modelling and calculations are reported in the supporting documentation '01 crop production - Québec.pdf' available on ecoinvent reports web page (<https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/File/Reports>).
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Literature and statistics data, opinions of experts in the field of agricultural production and agroeconomists.

exchanges.description: Total amount of active substance/s of pesticides needed for the production of oat grain is calculated to be circa 3.00E-04 kg. Pesticide/s used in this dataset is/are: 'glyphosate', 'nitrile-compound', 'pesticide, unspecified', 'phenoxy-compound'. The total amount of active substance/s is doubled in order to account for the packaging of the dilluted product of pesticide/s that is/are applied. Therefore, 6.00E-04 kg of packaging for pesticides is justified with this exchange.

exchanges.description: Global average LUC emissions according 2nd edition of the Quantis-modified tool developed by Blonk Consultants 'WFLDB-adapted-Blonk 2014 direct-land-use-change-assessment-tool_2015-05-18a.xlsx', tab. 'Country & land use unknown'. The emission are based on the relative change in production areas in all countries for a given crop. The weighted average is used which takes into acount relative difference in crop expansion into primary forest, secondary forest, grassland, perennial and annual land.

exchanges.description: Calculated value based on literature. The gross energy is calculated using following formula; gross energy (MJ) = crude protein (kg)*23.04 (MJ/kg)+crude fat (kg)*38.96 (MJ/kg)+crude fibre (kg)*17.95 (MJ/kg)+carbohydrates (kg)*17.17 (MJ/kg) (formula based on expert opinion, cross referenced; Diepenbrock, 2012, Energy Balance in Crop Production). The product composition is extracted from Agroscope Food database (http://www.agroscope.admin.ch/index.html?lang=en, accessed 20151028)
